title: 103_s1208
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the Federal Government took over. The historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were initially cared for by local government units. Later, the Federal Government, through the National Park Service, took over responsibility for preserving and maintaining these historic sites. Financial constraints and increased responsibilities have hindered the government from meeting the capital needs of these sites. The Federal Government has struggled to meet the capital needs of historic sites like Congress Hall and Independence Hall in Philadelphia. Minting a United States coin could help fund the maintenance and preservation of these buildings. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 coins made of 90% silver and 10% copper, weighing 26.73 grams and with a diameter of 1.500 inches. The design will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, symbolizing national shrines of liberty. Each coin will display the coin's value and inscriptions. The coins issued under this Act will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, symbolizing national shrines of liberty. They will be legal tender and have inscriptions of the year "1994" and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single Mint facility for up to one year after enactment. SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge of $7 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount as well. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws is still required. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary collects surcharges from coin sales under this Act. 50% goes to the Treasury to reduce the national debt, and 50% goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for capital improvements and other needs at Independence National Historic Park. The Independence Hall Preservation Fund aims to create an endowment fund for capital improvements, fund replacement projects for buildings, and address other needs to enhance respect for Independence National Historic Park. SEC. 10. AUDITS. The Comptroller General of the United States can examine the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's books and records related to expenditures. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND. Coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund provisions. SEC. 12. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure that issuing coins under this Act will not cost the government. Adequate security for payment is required before any coin can be issued. To issue coins under this Act, payment must be guaranteed through full payment, satisfactory security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
